I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In 2003, the Government of Viet Nam issued the Decree on Efficient Utilization of 
Energy and Energy Conservation.1 Subsequently in 2005, the Ministry of Industry and Trade 
(MOIT) prepared a National Targeted Program on Energy Efficiency and Conservation (EEC) 
for the period 2006–2015, which was approved by the Prime Minister on 14 April 2006. The 
Program called for a concerted effort in improving energy efficiency, reducing energy losses, 
and instituting measures for improving energy conservation in all sectors of the economy. The 
Program has time-bound targeted components and projects, with specific objectives and targets 
to be achieved by 2015 and beyond. 
2.  MOIT requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) 
to support the implementation of the Program, particularly in achieving the energy conservation 
targets set for the industry sector. On the basis of the request, this TA2 was formulated to assist 
MOIT in undertaking steps to achieve the Program targets set for the industry sector. The 
design and monitoring framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Between 1990 and 2004, Viet Nam's energy consumption increased by about 11% per 
annum, 1.5 times the gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate during the same period.   
Projections made by Viet Nam’s Institute of Energy envisage that energy demand will grow at 
about 8% per annum until 2020 (GDP is projected to grow at 7.6% until 2015 and 7.2% 
thereafter until 2020). Currently energy utilization in Viet Nam can be characterized by (i) a lack 
of awareness of the benefits of energy conservation, (ii) a lack of skilled human resources to 
implement demand side management, and (iii) high losses and low efficiency due to use of 
obsolete  technologies  and  equipment.  Initial  studies  undertaken  by  MOIT  show  that  the 
potential for energy conservation in the industry sector is about 20% of the current energy 
consumption level and this potential is untapped. The high energy demand coupled with the lack 
of energy conservation measures has led to shortages in electricity supply, thus necessitating 
new investments in generation that could otherwise have been deferred. 
4.  Viet Nam’s industry sector is the largest energy consumer, accounting for 36% of the 
country’s total energy consumption in 2006. This share will increase to 42% and 44% in 2010 
and 2020, respectively. In terms of electricity consumption, that sector is also the biggest 
consumer, accounting for about 46%. Thus, implementing energy saving measures in  industry  
will help reduce the demand for electricity and other energy fuels (fuel oil, diesel, coal, and 
natural gas), which in turn will reduce the need for new investments in electricity generation and 
energy production and consequently reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. 
5.  Viet Nam’s industrial energy intensity was 0.50 ton of oil equivalent (toe)/$1,000 of GDP 
in 2002 and increased to 0.66 toe/$1,000 in 2006 (the corresponding values for Thailand and 
Malaysia are 0.40 and 0.38 toe/$1,000). The high energy intensity reflects inefficient utilization 
of energy in industry. which is largely due to (i) use of inefficient equipment and outdated 
production processes leading to high energy losses; and (ii) lack of regular energy management 
practices and energy audits within industrial enterprises. The latter is important as, without 
energy audits, the potential for energy conservation cannot be identified and tapped. Further, 
                                                
1  Decree No. 102/2003/ND-CP dated 03 September 2003. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 24 May 2007.

2
lack of awareness of the benefits of energy conservation prevents commercial enterprises from 
investing in energy conservation. 
6.  The National Targeted Program on Energy Efficiency and Conservation is Viet Nam’s first 
comprehensive plan for setting up an institutional mechanism for sustained energy efficiency 
and  conservation  in  all  sectors  of  the  economy.  The  Program  uses  economic  incentives 
together with administrative measures to put in place day-to-day energy conservation practices 
in the whole society. The Program aims at achieving specific targets within a timeframe, to bring 
about actual reductions in energy production and consumption. 
7.  The specific objectives of the Program are to (i) formulate and implement a framework for 
effective management of EEC within the government, enterprises, and public services, and  
society as a whole; (ii) establish a model for EEC management and apply the model to 40% of 
the  designated  energy  consumers/enterprises3 during  the  period  2006–2010  and  to  the 
remaining 60% by 2015; (iii) formulate and enforce an energy-efficient building code for all new 
buildings  to  be  constructed  after  2008;  (iv)  achieve  3%–5%  reduction  of  the  total  energy 
consumption in the country during 2006–2010 and 5%–8% reduction during 2011–2015 (this is 
equivalent to saving 5 million toe and 13 million toe in the two periods, respectively, based on a 
business-as-usual scenario); (v) reduce energy consumption in the industry sector by 5% in 
2006–2010 and 8% in 2011-2015 (equivalent to energy savings of 2.6 and 5.0 million toe).  
8.  The  Government  plans  to  institute,  through  a  decree,  best  practices  in  energy 
management  in  industry  at  the  enterprise  level  as  an  integral  part  of  an  enterprise’s 
business  .plan.  To  attain  this  goal,  necessary  steps  have  been  identified  They  are  to  (i) 
establish  energy  managers,  who  will  be  responsible  for  monitoring  energy  use  in  their 
respective organizations and taking measures to reduce consumption; (ii) establish professional 
energy service companies (ESCOs) capable of providing a full package of energy services, 
including energy auditing, recommending feasible and practical measures to reduce energy 
consumption  based  on  an  investment  plan;  (iii)  undertake  energy  audits  of  selected  large 
industrial factories and recommend specific measures to cut down energy consumption; and (iv) 
by implementing some of the energy audit’s recommendations in step (iii), demonstrate the 
benefits of energy conservation on the productivity and profitability of  factories.  
9.  As an initial source of potential ESCOs, Viet Nam has a number of energy centers, such 
as the Institute of Energy, the Energy Center in Hanoi University of Technology, and the Energy 
Center in Ho Chi Minh City. There are also a number of small consulting companies active in 
energy conservation issues. The centers carry out research and educational activities and at the 
same time provide advisory services. However, they do not have sufficient technological know-
how, equipment, and experience to evolve into ESCOs.
10.  The  key  challenge  MOIT  faces  is  the  lack  of  expertise  and  resources  needed  to 
implement the steps identified (para. 8). MOIT also needs to mobilize in a coordinated manner 
the available domestic resources and international assistance in implementing the Program. 
The TA is designed to assist MOIT to overcome those constraints and to realize the energy 
conservation  opportunities  in  large  industrial  enterprises  by  upgrading  the  skills  of  energy 
managers, followed by identifying energy consumption patterns in the selected industries and 
then undertaking energy audits that will lead to specific investment plans for achieving energy 
savings in an economical manner. The TA would result in a strong demonstration effect for the

3
whole industry sector and would build confidence in the benefits of energy conservation. The TA 
is included in the Country Program and Strategy for 2007–2010. It is an integral part of ADB’s 
planned  assistance  to  Viet  Nam’s  energy  sector,  which  includes  expanding  the  electricity 
generation and transmission system, establishing an electricity market, supporting power sector 
reform, increasing energy efficiency and conservation, and utilizing renewable energy. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The TA will promote energy conservation in the industry sector in Viet Nam so as to 
substantially reduce energy consumption while delivering a higher level of energy services to 
the  sector.  The  envisaged  impact  of  the  TA  is  the  establishment  of  energy-efficient  best 
practices in the industry sector. Specifically, the TA will assist MOIT in achieving the target of 
5% and 8% reduction of energy consumption in large industrial enterprises by 2010 and 2015, 
respectively.  The  TA  will  provide  MOIT  with  the  much-needed  expertise  and  tools  for  (i) 
designing and developing training methods and materials for energy managers in industrial 
enterprises; (ii) designing and conducting a survey of energy consumption in selected industrial 
enterprises, thus creating a basis for analyzing energy consumption patterns in industry; (iii) 
establishing ESCOs that can provide auditing services and advise industrial enterprises on 
energy conservation measures; (iv) piloting energy audits in selected industrial enterprises; and 
(v) translating the ensuing recommendations into an appropriate investment plan applicable for 
the audited enterprises to implement as well as advising them on financing so as to realize the 
energy-saving potential in a profitable manner.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA is structured into five components, some of which will be conducted in parallel. 
The five components and their corresponding expected outputs are described below.  
13. Component 1: Survey of Energy consumption in Industrial Enterprises. The survey 
will collect, analyze, and identify patterns of energy consumption; examine features of energy 
management and accounting in industrial factories; and categorize them according to existing 
Vietnamese classification. The analyses will identify the areas for improving both the physical 
infrastructure and managerial approaches. This component will involve (i) designing a survey 
methodology  including  the  criteria  for  selecting  factories  to  be  included  in  the  survey;  (ii) 
conducting a survey of a number of factories using the survey sample and methodology, the 
results of which will be used to calibrate the survey method and sample for the intended number 
of factories; (iii) analyzing the collected data and information to determine (a) the current energy 
consumption  patterns  for  machinery  and  equipment,  (b)  the  relationship  between  energy 
accounting, production, and energy consumption; (iv) recommending action to improve energy 
consumption characteristics for each industrial category;  and (v) estimating carbon dioxide 
(CO ) emission level of the whole sector based on the survey results. 
2
14. Component  2:  Development  of  a  Training  Program  for  Energy  Managers. This 
component will produce a standard curriculum and associated materials for training technical 
staff of industrial enterprises, and staff of energy centers who will work on the management of 
energy issues in the industry sector. The curriculum will be tailored to the Vietnamese situation 
and will be self-contained and reproducible. The training program will educate technical and 
managerial staff about the processes and key factors that influence energy consumption, and 
identify areas for conserving energy in industrial factories. Activities for this component will 
include consulting with existing energy centers and institutes in preparing the energy training

4
curriculum, consisting of integrated modules each addressing an aspect of energy management 
in industry; and conducting short training courses using the developed materials and methods 
for selected energy managers and technical staff. The training will be conducted on two fronts: 
training of energy managers on setting up energy management systems; and energy efficiency 
technical  training  for  the  engineers  and  other  technical personnel. Training  on  the  energy 
management  system,  which  will  prepare  companies  for  long-term  sustainability  of  energy 
efficiency  initiatives,  will  include  organizing  an  energy  group,  prioritizing  energy  efficiency 
objectives and targets, setting energy efficiency performance indicators, communicating EEC-
related matters throughout the organization, and developing and implementing programs to 
achieve EEC goals and targets. The technical training will include EEC technologies, energy 
audit, data collection and on-site measurements, and data analysis and financial analysis. The 
intention is for the Energy Center in the Hanoi University of Technology; the Energy Center in 
Ho Chi Minh City, and the Institute of Energy to retain the training methods and materials for 
sustainable application in the future.   
15. Component 3: Conducting Energy Audits of Selected Large Industrial Enterprises.
This component will conduct energy audits of selected large industrial enterprises, analyze the 
results to determine the measures to enhance energy efficiency, and recommend them to 
enterprise  managers  for  implementation.  It  will  also  prepare  a  plan  to  implement  these 
recommendations including the costs required for equipment/process retrofitting. Activities in 
this component will include (i) identifying, in collaboration with component 1 (survey),, industrial 
enterprises of designated categories for energy audits; (ii) planning and conducting full energy 
audits;  (iii)  preparing  audit  reports  that  analyze  issues  and  problems,  and  recommending 
improvements, particularly for physical infrastructure, management, and corporate culture with 
respect to energy use; and (iv) suggesting a concrete plan for applying the recommended 
measures, including an investment plan. 
16. Component  4:  Upgrading  the  Capacity  of  Existing  Energy  Centers  into 
Professional ESCOs. This component will help set up several self-sustained ESCOs that can 
provide a full range of energy services to interested industrial enterprises, including auditing, 
training, and assisting in implementing measures for energy conservation. The local experts 
who work in components 1–3 will acquire good knowledge necessary for ESCOs services. This 
component involves (i) assessing the capacity of existing energy centers in Viet Nam with 
regard to staff skills and technical capability in providing energy services; (ii) identifying the 
technical and human resources gaps that need to be bridged to bring these centers to the level 
of independent ESCOs; (iii) preparing a plan to bridge these gaps; (iv) preparing a list of 
necessary equipment and the associated costs; training course needs; and providing initial 
training in conjunction with a subcomponent  of component 2. 
17. Component 5: Devising a Mechanism for Financing Energy Conservation Plans for 
Industrial  Enterprises.  This  component  will  develop  a  financing  modality  that  will  help 
industrial enterprises access financial sources for investment in EEC. The financing modality will 
facilitate mobilization of the possible multilateral financial sources (ADB included) and channel 
them, through local financial institutions (LFIs), to industrial enterprises. Such financial modality 
will ensure smooth linkages between financial sources with energy conservation projects. This 
component involves (i) holding dialogues with LFIs to assess their perception of the risk in 
financing energy conservation projects, their capability to appraise these projects and to assess 
the associated risks; (ii) preparing a plan to upgrade LFI capabilities; (iii) conducting dialogues 
with  interested  industrial  enterprises,  especially  those  that  have  been  provided  with  the 
investment plans under component 4 so as to estimate a market potential for financing; and (iv)

5
preparing a protocol for negotiating an agreement between potential development partners and 
LFIs that are willing to serve as intermediaries to finance energy conservation projects.   
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,160,000 equivalent. The TA will be cofinanced 
on a grant basis by the Spanish Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance ($425,000) and the 
Government of France through the Agence Française de Développement4 ($500,000), and 
administered by ADB. The Government will finance $235,000 equivalent in kind by providing 
counterpart staff, office space and facilities, reports, and support services. The detailed cost 
estimates and a financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The Department of Science and Technology (DST) of MOIT will be the Executing Agency 
(EA) and the Energy Conservation Office of DST will be the Implementing Agency (IA) for the 
TA. The TA will be implemented over a 12-month period starting in April 2008. 
20.  An international consulting firm, providing the services of 20 person-month international 
experts and 24 person-month national experts, will be engaged by ADB in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time), using 
quality- and cost-based selection (80:20) and simplified technical proposals. The consultants 
are expected to possess (i) in-depth knowledge of industrial production processes, equipment 
and technologies, their energy use characteristics; (ii) extensive experience in designing and 
conducting energy surveys and energy audits in industry; and (iii) an excellent understanding of 
the energy and industry sectors in Viet Nam. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
21.  Equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as 
amended from time to time) and will be handed over to the Energy Conservation Office upon 
completion of the TA. Procurement of energy audit equipment, which may be necessary, will be 
defined during TA implementation. TA contingencies will be used for this procurement. The 
consultant  will  prepare  an  inception  report  outlining  the  work  program,  an  interim  report 
documenting work in progress, and a final report summarizing the project outputs and results. 
The TA outputs will include not only consultant reports but also survey reports, training materials, 
and the tested mechanism for financing EEC in industry. They will be disseminated by a variety 
of means (website, in-country workshops, electronic reports, etc.). 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $425,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Spanish Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance; and (ii) 
ADB administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to 
be financed on a grant basis by the Government of France through the Agence Française de 
Développement to the Government of Viet Nam for Supporting Implementation of the National 
Energy Efficiency Program Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  .The  implementation  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  the  services  of  a 
multidisciplinary  team  of  international  and  national  consultants.  An  international  firm  to  be 
engaged for the TA is expected to procure the services of both international and national experts 
to perform the TA assignment. The consultancy firm will be responsible for the quality and timely 
delivery of the entire assignment to meet the stated objective and output requirements. The 
assignment is expected to require 44 person-months of consulting services (20 international and 
24 national). The terms of reference for each component of the TA are described below. .The 
numbers in brackets indicate person-months. 
2.  The  international  consultants  (i)  are  expected  to  possess  in-depth  knowledge  of 
industrial production processes, equipment and technologies, their energy use characteristics, 
and the role of energy management in industry worldwide; (ii) will have experience in knowledge 
transfer, especially in conducting training courses for targeted audiences; and (iii) should have 
extensive experience in designing and conducting energy surveys and energy audits in industry. 
The international consultancy firm should avail itself of a financial specialist with strong hands-
on experience in financing EEC initiatives. 
3.  National  consultants  are  expected  to  possess  (i)  an  excellent  understanding  of  the 
energy and industry sectors in Viet Nam, (ii) expertise in applying methodologies for survey 
design and analyses, and (iii) extensive experience in energy auditing in industrial enterprises. 
A.  Component  1:  Survey  the  Energy  Consumption  in  Industrial  Enterprises 
(international  energy  conservation  practitioner  [4]  and  national  energy 
conservation specialist [5]) 
4.  The consultants will conduct a sector-wide survey of energy consumption in the industry 
sector and perform analyses to obtain a clear understanding of patterns and factors explaining 
the patterns. To this end the consultants will undertake these tasks. 
(i)  Conduct  a  broad  literature  review  of  past  studies,  including  results,  reports 
prepared by other projects such as those of the United Nations Development 
Programme (UNDP) and World Bank (WB); and identify results related to the 
energy surveys, audits, training relevant to this TA. 
(ii) Discuss  with  the  Ministry  of  Science  and  Technology,  Electricity  Regulatory 
Agency, and Viet Nam Electricity to obtain results of the ongoing UNDP and WB 
projects. Obtain information about the WB’s demand side management program; 
creation of the project agent, preparation of the guidelines for the WB project. 
(iii) Review  the  literature  to  get  information  about  previous  energy  consumption 
surveys in the industry sector and nationwide. Summarize the strengths and 
weaknesses of the past surveys, their results and usage. 
(iv)  Set up a proper sample size for the survey to be carried out, particularly based on 
the understanding of the industrial classification in Viet Nam, and suggest the 
optimal  feasible  sample  of  industrial  enterprises  for  the  survey  to  cover  all 
important industry subsectors. The sample should not be less than 50 industrial 
enterprises.

B.  Component 2: Develop a Program for Training Energy Managers (international 
energy conservation specialist [3] and national energy conservation educator [5]) 
5. The consultants will produce a standard curriculum and associated materials for training 
engineers  and  staff  of  industrial  enterprises,  energy  centers,  and  research  institutes.  The 
training program will give engineers and managers information about the process and key 
factors  that  influence  energy  consumption  and  areas  where  energy  can  be  conserved  in 
industrial enterprises. The training program has two parts: (i) training energy managers on 
developing and setting up energy management systems, and (ii) energy efficiency technical 
training for engineers and technical personnel.  The first part will prepare companies for long-
term sustainability of energy efficiency initiatives and should include organizing an energy group; 
developing an energy policy; prioritizing energy efficiency objectives and targets; setting energy 
efficiency metrics or performance indicators; communicating energy efficiency and conservation 
(EEC)-related matters throughout the organization; developing and implementing strategies and 
programs to achieve EEC goals and targets; and developing documentation such as EEC 
guidelines  and  procedures,  reviews,  system  audits,  and  monitoring  and  measurements  to 
anticipate problems and keep performance on track. The technical training (part 2) will include 
EEC technologies, energy audit, data collection and on-site measurements, and data analysis 
including use of statistical tools such as scatter-gram, histogram, cause-and-effect diagrams, 
and financial analysis.  The consultants working on this task will undertake these tasks. 
(i)  Review  available  public  awareness  materials  produced  to  date,  including 
guidelines, brochures, leaflets, etc.; and summarize the content, application, and 
usefulness of the materials. Distinguish between public awareness materials and 
specialized training materials. 
(ii)  In consultation with the Energy Conservation Office of the Department of Science 
and Technology (DST) and DST, and Institute of Energy, Energy Center in Hanoi 
University of Technology, Energy Center in Ho Chi Minh City, prepare an energy 
training curriculum, which comprises a reasonable number of integrated modules, 
each addressing an aspect of energy management in industry as described in the 
preceding paragraph.

Appendix 3 11
(iii)  Develop the full content of each module, including lecture notes, presentation 
materials, and experimental works, if necessary. Prepare, edit, and publish such 
materials in English and Vietnamese. 
(iv)  Assess the capability of the institutions cited in (ii), and propose a pilot training 
course for selected energy managers and engineers. 
(v)  Conduct a short training course in the northern, central, and southern regions, 
using the developed methodology and materials. 
(vi)  Work  with  the  Institute  of  Energy,  Energy  Center  in  Hanoi  University  of 
Technology, and Energy Center in Ho Chi Minh City to transfer the materials and 
knowledge so that these centers can maintain and conduct training on their own. 
C.  Component 3: Audit Selected Industrial Enterprises (international energy auditor 
[5] and national energy service specialist [6]) 
6.  The consultants will conduct a full-fledged energy audit in selected (based on the survey) 
industrial  enterprises  and  provide  fact-based  recommendations  for  achieving  energy 
conservation targets.  The audits should look at all the resources being used by the enterprise 
and  not  be  confined  to  energy  alone.  This  can  be  done  using  the  cleaner  production-
environmental  management  system  approach.  For  example,  saving  water  means  saving 
pumping energy and possibly energy used in water and effluent treatment; improving product 
quality reduces energy uses in rework or product rejects. The consultants are required to 
undertake the following specific tasks. 
(i)  Utilizing the outputs produced by the survey and the training,  prepare the criteria 
for selecting industrial enterprises for auditing; identify industrial enterprises that 
potentially  will  benefit  from  the  energy  conservation  improvement  in  each 
industrial designated category; and set up a list of enterprises to be audited. The 
enterprises to be audited should not be less than 10. 
(ii)  Prepare  an  audit  plan  for  each  enterprise  in  liaison  with  the  respective 
management; prepare a detailed timetable involving auditing tasks and install 
audit equipment if necessary. 
(iii)  Conduct a full energy audit for the intended enterprises. 
(iv)  Prepare  an  audit  report  analyzing  issues  and  problems,  and  recommend 
measures particularly for physical infrastructure; and management and corporate 
culture with respect to energy use. 
(v)  Based on the audit results, propose a set of measures to enhance the energy use 
situation and recommendations to improve energy efficiency and conservation. 
Set out a detailed plan for implementing such recommendations including, if 
necessary,  the  investment  required  for  equipment/process  maintenance,  or 
overhaul. Suggest a concrete implementation plan for those measures. 
D.  Component 4: Upgrade Existing Energy Centers into Energy Service Companies 
(ESCOs) (international ESCO expert [3] and national experienced energy service 
provider [5] ) 
7.  The consultants are required to undertake the following specific tasks.

12 Appendix 3 
(i)  Assess existing energy centers in Viet Nam with regard to their human resource 
capability,  technical  capability,  expertise,  and  experience  in  providing  energy 
services to customers. 
(ii)  Identify the technical/organizational and human resources gaps that need to be 
filled to bring a center to the level of an independent energy service company. 
(iii)  Suggest a concrete plan to bridge gaps by means of suggested actions related to 
upgrading  technical  capacity;  human  resource  training,  and  reorganization,  if 
necessary.
(iv)  Prepare a costed list of necessary equipment and training course needs, and 
provide initial training in conjunction with a subcomponent of component 2. 
(v)  Conduct capacity enhancement and training as needed for the staff of the energy 
centers, and advice on a regular knowledge upgrade. 
E.  Component 5: Devise a Suitable Mechanism for Financing Energy Conservation 
Projects (international financial expert [5] and national financial specialist [3]) 
8.  The consultants are required to undertake the following tasks. 
(i)  Evaluate financial barriers in financing EEC projects. 
(ii)  Review the experience of past and ongoing programs with financial support to 
EEC projects, especially the WB project and the UNDP project; draw lessons of 
success and difficulties in those programs. 
(iii)  Assess the capacity of LFIs with respect to providing funding to EEC projects; 
assess their perception of risks, their capability to appraise EEC projects. 
(iv)  Estimate the market potential for financing in EEC projects, taking into account 
the results of components 1, 2, and 3. 
(v)  Suggest a plan to upgrade the capability of LFIs with respect to risk mitigation, 
project appraisal. 
(vi)  Prepare guidelines that detail the steps for creating a financial modality that will 
mobilize external multilateral as well as domestic resources for funding EEC 
projects. Such a modality should link the external sources, through the LFIs, to 
the industrial enterprises that require funding for their EEC projects.
